results.title: Kathe Kollwitz
results.creator_credit: Norbert Bunge, Ron Orders and Cinecontact
results.brief_description: The life of Kathe Kollwitz is portrayed through her diaries and letters. Kollwitz was an artist who worked with graphic media - lithography, etching and woodcuts, and was aware of the problems of the urban working class and wanted her art to communicate directly with an audience.

results.title: Kath and Kim. Series 2 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ted Emery, Gina Riley, Jane Turner, Mark Ruse and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Second series of the acerbic slice-of-life comedy show, “Kath & Kim” satirises the ambitions, aesthetics, language and aspirations of the working class. Kath (Jane Turner), a forty-something homeowner, fashion and fitness conscious woman, is newlywed to Kel (Glenn Robbins) the butcher. The bane of Kath’s life is her disgruntled, spoilt and indulged daughter Kim, a tasteless, overweight and overbearing fashion victim. Written and created by Gina Riley and Jane Turner. The announcement: Kath struggles with her libido and flagging marriage to Kel; Kim tries to win back her estranged husband, Brett. Inside out: Kim and Brett consider renovations, as well as procreation. The Moon: Second best friend Sharon helps out Kim despite her appalling demeanour; Sharon attends a class reunion; Kath plans a honeymoon. Obsession: Kath and Kel embark upon a new health and fitness regime; Kim struggles with her choices as a wife, humiliating Brett; Sharon takes up river dancing; Kath and Kel attend a plastic surgery clinic. My Boyfriend: Brett and Kim become separated in the largest furniture store in the Southern hemisphere; Sharon acquires a boyfriend; the netball final becomes a heated affair. Another announcement: Kim and Kath go shopping for the baby; Brett and Kim attend birthing classes, clashing over a range of issues. The Shower: Kath meets Kel’s sleazy best mate Sandy; Sharon plans Kim’s baby shower. The Hideous Truth: Kim awaits the birth of her child; Kath experiences flashbacks from her tumultuous first marriage.

results.title: Norma
results.creator_credit: William Fitzwater, Sandro Sequi, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Australian Opera
results.brief_description: Norma, the opera by Bellini, libretto by Felice Romani, based on a drama by Alexandre Soumet and directed by Sandro Sequi, is set in Gaul during the Roman occupation about 50 BC. Norma, the Druid High priestess, sung by Dame Joan Sutherland, breaks her vows of chastity with the Roman Pollione, sung by Ron Stevens. In a tangled tale of love and tragedy, the two lovers pay the ultimate sacrifice for their love and die together. Features singers Clifford Grant (Oroveso), Trevor Brown (Flavio), Margreta Elkins (Adalgisa), Etela Piha (Clotilde), and The Australian Opera Chorus. Also features The Elizabethan Sydney Orchestra conducted by Richard Bonynge. Recorded at the Sydney Opera House on 1 August 1978 and produced for television in association with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Restored and released in 1991 by The Australian Opera. Sung in Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Norm and Ahmed (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tristram Miall and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Twenty years after its creation, Norm and Ahmed, remains a classic in Australian literature. This video of the play features the well-known actor Max Cullen as Norm and Alex Pinder as Ahmed. The action centres on a midnight meeting between Norm, an average Australian, who embodies the ocker image and Ahmed, an urbane Pakistan student. The chance encounter starts off in a friendly enough manner, but underneath Norm’s veneer of mateyness lies a distrust of the unfamiliar and a defensiveness which turns nasty when Norm feels threatened. The themes of racism and prejudices in the play are still pertinent today.
